Other members of the Expedition emphatically 
deny that they were 'cross examined' or gave 'varying 
opinions'. 
Apart from the facts as asserted by these 
Officers I would ask you to consider for a moment the probabilities of this case. In taking a series of 
wind observations the observer naturally refers their 
directions to the 'true' or 'magnetic' meridian according 
to which of these is most conveniently presented to his 
view. 
Thus in a Ship winds are recorded 'magnetic' 
because they are most conveniently indicated by referring 
to the Compass; whereas on shore, vanes or bearings of 
objects indicating the 'true' meridian, enable 'true' 
directions of the wind to be more easily obtained. 
On applying such common sense rules to the 
conditions of Mr Royds' journey there will be seen the 
strongest probability that the winds were recorded 'true'. 
The outward course of this party was S.E. 'true'. 
All day long and every day constant attention was 
exercised in keeping a 'true' course. The tracks of 
the sledges were 'true' and therefore the direction in 
which they were halted at night. A sense of 'true' 
direction was vital to the party.
